Award.AbstractNarration:
The topics addressed in the project concern partial differential equations arising in the study of fluid dynamics. In particular, we study the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations for the motion of a viscous liquid, the Euler equations (and their models) for the motion of an inviscid liquid, and a class of scalar equations arising naturally from the mentioned systems through approximations in physically important settings. In the first part, regarding the Navier-Stokes equations, we intend to explore the anisotropy introduced by the oscillatory structure of solutions, in order to construct classes of large data leading to global well-posedness. The second part of the project is geared towards gaining a deeper understanding of the ill-posedness of a class of active scalar equations, based on the properties of the second iterate. The analysis focuses particularly on the equations where the nonlinearity is given by a Fourier multiplier whose symbol is anisotropic and/or even (the porous media equation and the magneto-geostrophic equation). The third objective of this project is to investigate a system of PDEs simulating the fundamental features of the vorticity-stretching phenomena in the three-dimensional incompressible Euler equations.

The project seeks to advance the understanding of the dynamics described by the equations of fluid dynamics by methods of rigorous mathematical analysis. These partial differential equations represent a basic tool for modeling many natural phenomena and technological applications. For instance, the equations describing fluid flow (on which an important part of this project concentrates) are used in weather prediction, climate research, and various technological applications, such as the design of optimal aerodynamical and hydrodynamical shapes. The equations of fluid dynamics are notoriously difficult to solve, even with the help of the largest computers. Some of these difficulties constitute part of the problem, but some are due to the fact that our mathematical understanding of the equations themselves is incomplete. From the analytical point of view, these equations account for interactions of a broad range of space- and time-scales in a highly non-linear fashion. Due to this intrinsic complexity, the accuracy needed to fully resolve the underlying phenomena via numerical computations is out of reach for the foreseeable future. Advances in theoretical understanding of these partial differential equations are vital for the validation of the models and for an accurate interpretation of numerical results. In the final analysis, the main task of the theoretical investigation is to find simple and natural parameters that control the behavior of the solutions. Once a good set of such parameters is known, it becomes much easier to design practical methods for calculating the solutions numerically.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of the project address the problem whether the equations, that are believed to describe flows of fluids and gases, indeed account for all phenomena and give and give an accurate mathematical description of reality. Therefore, it is necessary to determine if the mathematical model is well-posed, that is if the equations have appropriate solutions, if so - are the solutions unique and how prone are they to changes under perturbations of the initial conditions. Even without the rigorous confirmation of well-posedness of the model numerical approximations are widely used to model flows in situations rooted in physics and engineering applications. It becomes then necessary to be able to ensure that the model is valid for instance by keeping track of certain quantities whose bounds imply regularity. The less and the easier the quantities we keep track of the more useful the criterion is. Moreover, even if a rigorous proof of well-posedness in the general case is out of reach, it is often illuminating to address cases where a special structure is imposed on the solutions.

The classical theory of the Navier-Stokes equations admits well-posedness if initial data are small in a certain sense. Several results have been obtained in the last two decades where classes of large initial data lead to regular global solutions. A great part of the project was devoted to constructing classes of data, truly large, that give rise to global strong solutions. We succeed in constructing a wide class of such data, offering criteria that allow for construction of other examples.

Mathematical study of fluid dynamics is concerned also with equations that are derived from the classical set of equations (Navier-Stokes equations in case of flows of viscous liquids and Euler equations in case of inviscid flows). A prominent example of such are the primitive equations of the ocean. Their analysis poses a slightly different set of challenges. In particular, the three-dimensional character of the pressure (it is only two-dimensional in the primitive equations) comes at the cost of the lack of an evolutionary equation for the fluid’s velocity in the vertical direction (it is recovered indirectly from the incompressibility condition). Due to wide-spread applications of the equations in problems encountered in engineering, climate modeling, and weather prediction, the problem of the well-posedness of the primitive equations is an important one. In part of the project, we succeed to prove well-posedness in case of continuous initial data, in particular no initial differentiability is needed.

The third part of the project addressed well-posedness of a class of active scalar equations that model the dynamo effect in planetary cores. Simplified mathematical models of these equations were also under consideration. We succeeded to prove several results concerning existence and regularity of solutions.

Outcomes obtained within the project constitute part of a mathematical theory that aims at describing the behavior of liquids via rigorous analysis of partial differential equations. The obtained results enhance the state of knowledge in that field and offer applicable ways of ensuring that results obtained via numerical simulations indeed describe physical behavior of liquids. 

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Walter M Rusin
